DAC7CFF4E7484465878A92E568C5CE23.description:
Identify ways in which animals are considered
helpful or harmful to humans and to the
environment.

3358ECB04F354182B6B567B37D80841A.description:
Describe conditions for the care of a small
animal, and demonstrate responsible care in
maintaining the animal for a few days or
weeks.

BD7AC51B1FA0411686EF5BBA4C5085AC.description:
Identify and give examples of ways that small
animals avoid predators, including
camouflage, taking cover in burrows, use of
keen senses and flight.

7174B027B42649F0BBEA51C375B94662.description:
Describe the relationships of these animals to
other living and nonliving things in their
habitat, and to people.

856AB455FAFA42058AB0EB273FD2E2EC.description:
Identify each animal’s role within the food
chain. To meet this expectation, students
should be able to identify the animals as plant
eaters, animal eaters or decomposers and
identify other animals that may use them as a
food source.

15A3409D552344B8A1CF84F25938B288.description:
Recognize that small animals, like humans,
have homes where they meet their basic needs
of air, food, water, shelter and space; and
describe any special characteristics that help
the animal survive in its home

8F6E7FEDFA1B47D7A41B947B5F612F6E.description:
Compare and contrast small animals that are
found in the local environment. These
animals should include at least three
invertebrates—that is, animals such as insects,
spiders, centipedes, slugs, worms.

6FEBE5941BEB445787B3B7EFAE8D4CAD.description:
Recognize that there are many different kinds
of small crawling and flying animals, and
identify a range of examples that are found
locally.

AC2DF9E3DA794A878664E9C777AE224F.description:
Describe the general structure and life
habits of small crawling and flying
animals; e.g., insects, spiders, worms,
slugs; and apply this knowledge to
interpret local species that have been
observed.

66F6AC5E9FE84E38BB2195FCCA224FE9.description:
Topic E: Small Crawling and Flying
Animals: Overview
Students learn about the structure and life habits
of animals by studying small animals that live in
their own community. By investigating outdoor
spaces in and around the school and their homes,
students discover a wide range of animals that find
shelter and food within the local area. In studying
these animals, they learn about where animals
live, what they eat, what they are eaten by and
features of the animals that suit them to their
particular environment.

9CDFA69F820F452699B13BE0C619086B.description:
Describe ways in which temperature changes
affect us in our daily lives.

6BB2ADDDC3864EA2AA12C989CAF9A145.description:
Design and construct a device to keep
something hot or cold.

5B45FDB2AAAE48BDB948E13945F7A412.description:
Identify materials that insulate animals from
the cold; e.g., wool, fur and feathers; and
identify materials that are used by humans
for the same purpose.

2D46AC79188147E2B67088F9F8685D3F.description:
Describe the role of insulation in keeping
things hot or cold, and identify places where
some form of insulation is used; e.g.,
clothing, refrigerator, coolers, homes.

80F0C361F45E4765BB100B58A26C0400.description:
Describe, in general terms, how local
buildings are heated:
• identify the energy source or fuel
• recognize that most buildings are heated
by circulating hot air or hot water
• describe how heat is circulated through
the school building and through their own
homes.

065BF8C8285E46C48A56774EDD686394.description:
Identify ways in which the temperature in
homes and buildings can be adjusted; e.g.,
by turning a thermostat up or down, by
opening or closing windows, by using a
space heater in a cold room.

6E151A787F72413BA02FFCAC7FA2536D.description:
Recognize that the human body temperature
is relatively constant and that a change in
body temperature often signals a change in
health.

EFD77DA1DB3042E1A7ADA987246474D3.description:
Identify safe practices for handling hot and
cold materials and for avoiding potential
dangers from heat sources.

A5A02C70CA1544089236EE8C7D28F7FD.description:
Describe how heating and cooling materials
can often change them; e.g., melting and
freezing, cooking, burning.

9E427A82EE7C442AB2DA603805184751.description:
Describe temperature in relative terms, using
expressions, such as hotter than, colder than.

9EFF0B8DF2A748C2972270C8F1AC8F6B.description:
Recognize the effects of heating and
cooling, and identify methods for heating
and cooling.

D44858A457C5402983DD89570323597F.description:
Topic D: Hot and Cold Temperature: Overview
Students learn that materials are sometimes
changed by heating or cooling and that by
observing such changes, they can infer how hot or
cold an object is. They learn that thermometers
provide a helpful way to measure and describe the
hotness or coldness of things—a more reliable
way than provided by their own senses. Students
observe that temperatures can go up and down,
including the temperature of their surroundings
and the temperatures of particular objects within
it. They also learn about methods that are used to
control temperature in buildings and how
insulation is used to keep things hot or cold.

1B04FB0634094622A2B3BC72766CE770.description:
Compare and measure the strength of
magnets.

C9F437D09C904BCCAC32F828188B3DCC.description:
Demonstrate that most materials are
transparent to the effects of a magnet. A
magnetic field will pass through such
materials, whereas other materials interact
with a magnet

30E785BC5E474CEEA69A45782FBFAC0B.description:
Design and produce a device that uses a
magnet.

38C5820CD9C8464BBA96429716D170F0.description:
Recognize that magnets have polarity,
demonstrate that poles may either repel or
attract each other, and state a rule for when
poles will repel or attract each other.

9F1B7EE8E4C44A6382E0AFB1985CB4FD.description:
Recognize that magnets attract materials with
iron or steel in them; and given a variety of
metallic and nonmetallic objects, predict those
that will be attracted by a magnet.

29779AF4CC0B4478AF9874B1B10D0AC7.description:
Distinguish materials that are attracted by a
magnet from those that are not.

AE9A4BABFFD74BF5BD261C83E08AFE75.description:
Identify where magnets are used in the
environment and why they are used.

B582D216606540759F3D83521368CA27.description:
Describe the interaction of magnets with
other magnets and with common
materials

A35319AF24694A929E6A1EA3508742C4.description:
Topic C: Magnetism: Overview
Students explore the interaction of magnets with a
variety of materials found within their own
environment. By testing the effects of one magnet
on another, they learn that magnets show polarity
and that the strength of magnetic effects
diminishes with distance. They learn to
distinguish materials that are affected by magnets
from those that are not and learn how magnets can
be used in sorting objects, moving things and
holding things together.

FB9AB22BA5594E4392FA67351C39D926.description:
Explain why a given material, design or
component is appropriate to the design task.

85F9991E5C1E4AB79D9A19B4128D006A.description:
Adapt the design of a watercraft so it can be
propelled through water.

CA93FFED57F94973B528BE45A4715B2A.description:
Develop or adapt methods of construction that
are appropriate to the design task.

DA71A5D3DA08498F9000C092E1D236C6.description:
Evaluate the appropriateness of various
materials to the construction of watercraft, in
particular:
• the degree to which the material is
waterproof (not porous)
• the ability to form waterproof joints
between parts
• the stiffness or rigidity of the material
• the buoyancy of the material

CFFFA1A6C9A74945A44C0701424CD648.description:
Modify a watercraft to increase its stability in
water.

AF9CD311B75D41E592810A03AC8C4B6D.description:
Modify a watercraft to increase the load it will
carry.

1AA4706978BE4DDAAB316D9B50D5B4F6.description:
Assemble materials so they will float, carry a
load and be stable in water

C508EEF6E5CA421192374DEC719A6E39.description:
Alter or add to a floating object so that it will
sink, and alter or add to a nonfloating object
so that it will float

864AC30BE6234C3BAFB79D1E0B75E57D.description:
Describe, classify and order materials on the
basis of their buoyancy. Students who have
achieved this expectation will distinguish
between materials that sink in water and those
that float. They will also be aware that some
“floaters” sit mostly above water, while others
sit mostly below water. The terms buoyancy
and density may be introduced but are not
required as part of this learning expectation

7982CEE1053B40BB8A5F16D09B1E5CD2.description:
Construct objects that will float on and
move through water, and evaluate
various designs for watercraft.

8E2CB0D48C6240DEA87A841331D1755A.description:
Topic B: Buoyancy and Boats Overview: Students explore what sinks and what floats, and
what makes an effective watercraft. Through
building and testing a variety of floating objects,
students learn the importance of selecting
appropriate materials and the importance of
workmanship in shaping, positioning, fitting and
waterproofing their constructions, so they will do
the intended job. Along the way, students learn
about balance and stability and about different
methods that can be used in propelling a
watercraft. The concept of density is informally
developed in this topic

919958A41F384C99AE8D803FD827E14D.description:
Recognize human responsibilities for
maintaining clean supplies of water, and
identify actions that are taken to ensure that
water supplies are safe.

D10671BE29C34D429E2540D66A113F43.description:
Recognize that water is a component of many
materials and of living things.

4FCC01713E52441AAEFB979CCCF891D3.description:
Predict that a wet surface will dry more
quickly when exposed to wind or heating and
apply this understanding to practical
situations, such as drying of paints, clothes
and hair.

8F252B4E222D48B791E4D0C838CFEAD0.description:
Predict that the water level in open containers
will decrease due to evaporation, but the water
level in closed containers will not decrease.

6362F28372914018B301392FF4F7AC19.description:
Demonstrate an understanding that liquid
water can be changed to other states:
• recognize that on cooling, liquid water
freezes into ice and that on heating, it
melts back into liquid water with
properties the same as before
• recognize that on heating, liquid water may
be changed into steam or water vapor and
that this change can be reversed on cooling
• identify examples in which water is
changed from one form to another.

3F076C5C309441BD947828A362AC02E5.description:
Evaluate the suitability of different materials
for containing liquids. Students should
recognize that materials such as writing paper
and unglazed pottery are not waterproof and
would not be suitable as containers; but that
waxed paper and glazed pottery are
waterproof and, thus, could be used in
constructing or lining a liquid container

05F3300A27914619B850E03AEDE4870A.description:
Compare the amount of liquid absorbed by
different materials; e.g., students should
recognize that some forms of paper are very
absorbent but other forms of paper are not.

35510300964C4D68AA11688C158C0131.description:
Compare water with one or more other
liquids, such as cooking oil, glycerine or water
mixed with liquid detergent. Comparisons may be based on characteristics, such as
colour, ease of flow, tendency of drops to
form a ball shape (bead), interactions with
other liquids and interactions with solid
materials.

5E01C9C9BE29420989824EE4D1E3F03C.description:
Recognize and describe characteristics of
liquids:
• recognize and describe liquid flow
• describe the shape of drops
• describe the surface of calm water.

FD157277B4CD4A8B83D6B34869906364.description:
Describe the interaction of water with
different materials, and apply that
knowledge to practical problems of
drying, liquid absorption and liquid
containment.

483677DE3AF04CC3904328C001AA03E6.description:
Describe some properties of water and
other liquids, and recognize the
importance of water to living and
nonliving things.

39DD08AA63394C0E8F7FCF0DAF2EAE44.description:
Topic A: Exploring Liquids Overview: Students learn about the nature of liquids and the
interactions of liquids with other materials. They
explore liquids by examining droplets, by
watching liquids trickle down slopes, by
investigating flow rates and by observing liquid
interactions with a variety of materials. They
learn that some materials are impervious to
liquids, while others are absorbent, and that some
liquids mix readily while others do not. They
observe that liquid water can be changed to ice or
to steam, and back again, if heated and cooled,
and that wet materials dry out when left open to
the air. Through this topic, students learn that
water is our most important liquid, that we use
water in many ways, and that water is essential to
life.

353EBCD90352475BA494FBFDBFA36042.description:
Demonstrate positive attitudes for the study of science and for the application of science in
responsible ways.

120072702474486981F4B11ED3704EFA.description:
Demonstrate positive attitudes for the study of science and for the application of science in
responsible ways.

BF8AD3F282F346E9BBDBE6D2D78B906B.description:
• communicate results of construction activities,
using oral language, captioned pictures and simple
graphs (pictographs and bar graphs)
• describe the product and describe and explain the
processes by which it was made
• identify applications for the product that was made.

61914702754F4F7B9F9070A06620CB90.description:
• attempt, with guidance, a variety of strategies to
complete tasks
• identify steps followed in constructing the object
and in testing it to see if it works
• engage in all parts of the task and allow others to
make their contributions
• identify materials used and how they were used
• use, with guidance, print and other sources of
information provided. Sources may include
library, classroom, community and computer-based
resources

0AA71054C4D14A09A21BF604BA36BDE0.description:
• identify the purpose of the object to be constructed:
What structure do we need to make? What does it
need to do?

B2C76AE15AE945FF8FF5F5C4D8304BC7.description:
Construct, with guidance, an object that
achieves a given purpose, using materials
that are provided.Note* Construction tasks will involve building objects
that float and are stable in water.

F41FFABFCEF44978934285E0285ECC36.description:
• describe what was observed, using captioned pictures
and oral language
• describe and explain results; explanations may reflect
an early stage of concept development
• identify applications of what was learned
• identify new questions that arise from the
investigation.

59D8165531174AFB94549B1175C78E8B.description:
• manipulate materials and make observations that are
relevant to questions asked
• carry out simple procedures identified by others
• identify materials used and how they were used
• use, with guidance, print and other sources of
information provided. Sources may include library,
classroom, community and computer-based resources

3CE4CBDC33DB44CD8EA1BE4CC2CE0C13.description:
• ask questions that lead to exploration and
investigation
• identify one or more possible answers to questions
asked by themselves and others. Ideas may take the
form of predictions and hypotheses

829126622E294E9E9F3EDB1075624405.description:
Recognize pattern and order in objects and
events studied; and, with guidance, record
procedures and observations, using pictures
and words; and make predictions and
generalizations, based on observations.

D14251239A544E19AA648889C161A50B.description:
Investigate, with guidance, the nature of things,
demonstrating an understanding of the
procedures followed.
